brief_summary.textblock:
Spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA) is a hereditary disorder with movement incoordination. The
      ataxia performed low intra-cortical facilitation mainly due to the degenerative cerebellum.
      Noninvasive sensory stimulations such as peripheral electrical stimulation were reported to
      modulate the excitability of the motor excitability. Neuromuscular electrical stimulation
      (NMES) was proposed as a neuromodulation tool for the aberrant motor excitability on the
      SCA. This study aims to investigate the effect of NMES on the motor excitability in the SCA,
      and the differentiation on the central or peripheral motor excitability changed by the NMES.

clinical_study.brief_title: Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation on Median Nerve Facilitates Low Motor Cortex Excitability in Human With Spinocerebellar Ataxia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Clinical diagnosis of Spinocerebellar ataxia

          -  No history of epilepsy

          -  No other neuromuscular disorder

          -  No fracture within the last six months and restricted movement on the upper extremity

          -  Limited trembling hand allowed for the EMG recording.

intervention.description: All groups received an accumulated 30-minute NMES (25 Hz, on/off: 800ms/800ms) intervention on median nerve.

primary_outcome.description: Measure of changes in Central Motor Excitability by motor evoked potential and silent period that are measured by transcranial magnetic stimulation.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, in experiment, 0 minute, 10 minutes, and 20 minutes.

primary_outcome.description: Measure of changes in peripheral motor excitability by Maximum M wave and H reflex
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, in experiment, 0 minute, 10 minutes, and 20 minutes.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Safety Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Treatment
